winners.tagline: Spiro is an accessible, cheap, and portable diagnostic tool for the detection of Parkinsonâ€™s disease.

prizes.prize_name: Best use of Google Cloud Platform

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content:
We discovered a diagnostic tool used by doctors in the diagnosis of Parkinson's patients using the "static spiral test." A patient draws a spiral on a piece of paper, and a doctor takes a guess depending on the quality of the spiral whether the patient has Parkinson's or not.

We then set out to create a portable, cheap, and accessible application which could accurately assess the severity of Parkinson's in any user in a short amount of time.

Spiro is the result of that mission.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: At its core, Spiro is a mobile application which informs users whether it is likely or not that they have Parkinson's. The app presents users with a dotted image of a spiral, which they must trace using either their finger or a stylus on a touch screen. Their trace is analyzed by a machine learning algorithm, which reports back to the user whether they are potentially at risk of Parkinson's or not based on their tracing.

description_sections.heading: How we built it
description_sections.content: First, we used static spiral test data from Istanbul University to recreate spirals of individuals with and without Parkinson's using matplotlib (python). We cleaned up the data by centering these spirals and made them have the same resolution and dimensions. Then, we built a convolutional neural network to train our TensorFlow model in Google Cloud Platform. Time was spent optimizing the parameters (pool size, num convolutions, num neurons) to maximize accuracy.

description_sections.heading: Challenges we ran into
description_sections.content: It was difficult to manipulate all of the spiral data into a consistent format which would be usable by the program. In addition, setting up the Google Cloud Platform, having it support all of the packages we were using, and using it to train the model was fairly difficult and required a lot of research. Also, we had to play very many games against the network we were training in order to make it actually learn and not resort to a trivial local solution of guessing that the person always does or does not have Parkinson's, for example.

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that we're proud of
description_sections.content: Our model holds 96% accuracy in distinguishing between Parkinson's and non-Parkinson's results. Each of our team members would consistently score at only about 60% accuracy, far below the computer's discernment abilities. We also successfully developed an iOS application that instructs and allows users to take the static spiral test themselves.

description_sections.heading: What we learned
description_sections.content: We learned how to develop streamlined and functional Swift applications, how to set up and train machine learning models on Google Cloud Platform, how to effectively use Pandas to clean and mine relevant data, and how to use Firebase as a database to store the test results of our application.

description_sections.heading: What's next for Spiro
description_sections.content:
First, we plan to automatically train the model on the new data stored in the Firebase database after an arbitrary timeframe. Then, we plan to expand support to Android as a mobile platform. Finally, we plan to increase the depth of the model used and epochs trained in order to increase accuracy.

P.S. We also built an extra little mini-game which puts you against our algorithm. Come meet us and see if you can beat our model!

description_sections.heading: Built With
description_sections.content: firebase google-cloud keras numpy pandas python swift tensorflow

winners.tagline: Cross-platform mobile app to improve overall roadway safety

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: Today there are plenty of travel apps out there such as Google Maps and Waze. Unfortunately these apps are only concerned with getting you somewhere the fastest, not the safest. What if we could work with these apps to prioritize driver safety and make sure users are going the RiteWae?

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: Our app takes travel to the next level by ensuring your commute is on the safest route. Utilizing Google Maps API and Liberty Mutual's Shine API, our app can alert you of nearby dangers or hazards as well as provide you with the historical data for geographic areas.

description_sections.heading: How we built it
description_sections.content: We built our application using a MongoDB Stitch back-end & React Native front-end with a sprinkle of Liberty Mutual's Shine API and Google Maps API.

description_sections.heading: Challenges we ran into
description_sections.content: Along the way we struggled with implementing voice recognition on time. Ideally this app would have a completely hands free feature.... however this feature is not far off. In addition learning a new technology stack proved problematic with no prior experience among the team; however, it was a worthwhile endeavor.

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that we're proud of
description_sections.content: For half the team this was our first Hackathon, we just met this weekend and we still managed to build a fully functional prototype. Overcoming our various challenges as mentioned before was a fulfilling experience.

description_sections.heading: What we learned
description_sections.content: Teamwork makes the dream work. Additionally, motivation can come from unexpected sources -- such as a stray succulent lost in the wind.

description_sections.heading: What's next for RiteWae
description_sections.content: Data is in, not only do we provide safety as a service for our users, but over time as the app scales data sets from the users can be used to improve roadway infrastructure and the driving experience for everyone. Law enforcement may use this data to prioritize problem areas. Finally, the insurance sector may use this data to have better predictors into customer behavior patterns.

description_sections.heading: Built With
description_sections.content: android-studio expo.io google-maps javascript love mongodb react-native shine stitch

winners.tagline: Smash your opponents' towers while you stack your own.

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: We wanted to create a multiplayer game that was quick and enjoyable to play.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: A multiplayer tower-building game where you try to smash your opponent's towers while you stack your own.

description_sections.heading: How we built it
description_sections.content: We used a node.js backend server with a JavaScript canvas front-end. We used Socket.IO to communicate between our client and server.

description_sections.heading: Challenges we ran into
description_sections.content: We had difficulty getting the physics right. Early on, tall towers waved way too much and made it frustrating to build. On a similar note, as one may imagine, synchronizing a multiplayer physics-based game over the internet can prove challenging.

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that we're proud of
description_sections.content: We were able to fully build out and deploy a multiplayer game that anyone can jump into and enjoy.

description_sections.heading: What we learned
description_sections.content: We learned much about implementing a server-side physics engine with an HTML canvas on the front end, and we learned much about Socket.IO along the way.

description_sections.heading: What's next for Stack and Smash
description_sections.content: If interest is expressed in the project, we may end up adding some more of our envisioned features and stretch goals! (CPU battles, fire, bombs?!?)

winners.tagline: A light weight react native app that uses machine learning to detect skin tumors

description_sections.heading: TumorVision
description_sections.content:
A lightweight application for Android, iOS, and web environments to predict the diagnoses of a lesion on a patient's skin, made with the intent of being portable, scalable, and accessible. Built using Python, Flask, and React Native. Utilizes the libraries OpenCV, SciKitLearn, NumPy, and the Google cloud platform.

The application visually analyzes skin lesions from pictures to determine whether the lesions correspond to any known types of cancer or other significant dermataological conditions. When the application is executed, the client takes an image of a lesion on their skin using their smartphone, providing data about their age, gender, and the region of the body where the picture is taken. This is then sent to a server where it is compared with a ML model to predict the type of lesion on the skin, and to determine if it is cancerous. Afterwards, the client is sent back data about the potential characteristics of their disease. The ML model is trained using a data set of 10,000 images of skin lesions acquired from kaggle.com: https://www.kaggle.com/kmader/skin-cancer-mnist-ham10000 Limitations of the model include the size of the data set, and the number of images taken to evaluate a skin lesion.

description_sections.heading: Skin Cancer Types and Info, the types that we can detect
description_sections.content:
Actinic keratoses and intraepithelial carcinoma / Bowen's disease (akiec): Cancerous, treatable Bowen's disease, also known as squamous cell carcinoma in situ is a neoplastic skin disease. It can be considered as an early stage or intraepidermal form of squamous cell carcinoma. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bowen%27s_disease

basal cell carcinoma (bcc): Cancerous, treatable A type of skin cancer that begins in the basal cells. https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/basal-cell-carcinoma/symptoms-causes/syc-20354187

benign keratosis-like lesions (solar lentigines / seborrheic keratoses and lichen-planus like keratoses, bkl): Non-cancerous Seborrheic keratosis is one of the most common noncancerous skin growths in older adults. Seborrheic keratoses are normally painless and require no treatment. You may decide to have them removed if they become irritated by clothing or for cosmetic reasons. https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/seborrheic-keratosis/symptoms-causes/syc-20353878

dermatofibroma (df): Cancerous, treatable, grows slowly Dermatofibroma is a very rare type of skin cancer that begins in connective tissue cells in the middle layer of your skin (dermis). It grows slowly and rarely spreads beyond the skin. https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/dermatofibrosarcoma-protuberans/cdc-20352949

melanoma (mel): Cancerous, treatable if detected early Melanoma is the most serious type of skin cancer. Knowing the warning signs of skin cancer can help ensure that cancerous changes are detected and treated before the cancer has spread. Melanoma can be treated successfully if it is detected early. https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/melanoma/symptoms-causes/syc-20374884

melanocytic nevi (nv): Non-cancerous A usually noncancerous disorder of pigment-producing skin cells commonly called birth marks or moles. They can exist at birth or appear later. Rarely, melanocytic nevi can become cancerous. Most cases don't require treatment, but some cases require removal of the mole. https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/moles/symptoms-causes/syc-20375200

vascular lesions (angiomas, angiokeratomas, pyogenic granulomas and hemorrhage, vasc): Non-cancerous Pyogenic granulomas are skin growths that are small, round, and usually bloody red in color. Doctors can remove them through a variety of methods. https://www.healthline.com/health/pyogenic-granuloma

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content:
On campus, we have a huge problem with groups of people hoarding bird scooters inside their homes. The public can't access them, and chargers cant charge them

Call of the wild, sets out to change that by identifying hoarders by using nudge theory to convince them to release the birds into the wild

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: Using gps data we find clusters of birds using the HERE.com API and attempts to make the birds chirp on command

description_sections.heading: How we built it
description_sections.content: We used HERE.com api to make a custom map of the birds

description_sections.heading: Challenges we ran into
description_sections.content: Finding birds in the wild to test Getting the bird to chirp on command, with more practice and bird treats we expect them to learn this skill

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that we're proud of
description_sections.content: We are proud if the impact this application will have in the real world

description_sections.heading: What we learned
description_sections.content: How to use HERE.com API

description_sections.heading: What's next for Call of the wild
description_sections.content: We hope to work with other companies to prevent this inhumane hoarding and #UncageTheBirds

winners.tagline: A smart wardrobe so that you have more space to live and less worries about your clothing

prizes.prize_name: Best IoT Hack Using a Qualcomm Device

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: A lot of people, especially in big cities, live in small living spaces. A wardrobe takes a significant amount of space in every household. The main reason of the big space a wardrobe takes is because people have to open it in order to select their clothes. We have designed a system that will no longer require that. Our system will eliminate the large space wardrobes take and give everyone a little bit more livable space.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: Our system has a screen on top a wardrobe. In this system, a facial recognition tool runs to recognize the person. Then, the clothing inventory of that person is taken for the person to see. Our system can recommend clothing (based on the occasion that you are dressing for and the current weather). You can also select your own clothes through a select option. Our system also supports multiple people since we understand that there are usually more than one people living in a household.

description_sections.heading: How we built it
description_sections.content:
We have used Python to build a face recognition (microsoft face api,opencv) , get live weather data (open-weather-api) based on geolocation, clothing/apparel recognition (opencv, clarifai), a flask server for the front end of the application.

We have created a web-app using HTML,CSS and Javascript so that we can have a front end for our application.

We have used mongoDB stitch for the backend and database of the application.

description_sections.heading: Challenges we ran into
description_sections.content: FRONT END FRONT END FRONT END FRONT END FRONT END FRONT END FRONT END FRONT END FRONT END FRONT END

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that we're proud of
description_sections.content: FRONT END (since we actually have some stuff that works!) A running MongoDB stitch backend. A running Face Recognition and Apparel Recognition.

description_sections.heading: What we learned
description_sections.content: FRONT END

description_sections.heading: What's next for SmartDrobe
description_sections.content: We are planning to develop the front end to add all the functionality. We are also planning to build a small wardrobe so that we can physically show the amount of space we can save using this tool.

description_sections.content: clarifai css dragonboard face-api flask html javascript mongodb open-weather-map opencv python

winners.tagline: When it comes to the SnapDragon Board, a lot of people miss the opportunity to work with it, because of a linux base.

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: With background as club leadership, we know how hard it is to convince our members to pursue working with an IOS that they are unfamiliar with, but as soon as we show them the fist couple steps there curiosity takes care of the rest.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: This application will aid in teaching students about linux OS and help encourage them to strive to take a new initiative outside the class room to learn about something new, while also showcasing a how to on the ever growing platform of snapdragon

description_sections.heading: How we built it
description_sections.content: Having little experience with python (especially on the visual end) we built a python based UI app that allows students to learn all about Snapdragon and the powerful Linux operating system. Pairing up with the pygame library we were able to create a powerful app, whose educational value goes unmatched

description_sections.heading: Challenges we ran into
description_sections.content: Starting this project we knew that we wanted to get out of our comfort zone and learn something new. We decided that although we know some python, the idea of graphics with python seemed crazy. We had to learn about python, expand and build upon our seemingly little to no experience with both Linux and SnapDragon

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that we're proud of
description_sections.content: WE GOT SOMETHING WORKING. Oh yah, it isn't often that we are able to pick up a skill fast enough in order to get a working prototype. We grew as a team helping to build each others knowledge and to create a good UI experience.

description_sections.heading: What we learned
description_sections.content: That the Qualcomm SnapDragon board goes far beyond that of the capabilities of any hardware we have worked with in the past, in the compact package that it comes in.

description_sections.heading: What's next for Follow the SnapDragon
description_sections.content: We will continue to build on the skills that the application offers, making it easily accessible by people of all income and opportunities. The code that we wrote will be undergoing further development with non for profits that bringing skills like coding to places that usually would be unable to get the experience.

description_sections.heading: Built With
